History of NCL /Batten Disease
History of NCL /Batten Disease

• Most common group of progressive
• Most common group of progressive

neurodegenerative disorders in children
neurodegenerative disorders in children

• Actually first described by Otto-Christian Stengel in Norway (published in 1826) – however, 4 sibs with juvenile NCL in family died and were buried before Stengel could do autopsies
• Actually first described by Otto-Christian Stengel
in Norway (published in 1826) – however, 4 sibs
with juvenile NCL in family died and were buried
before Stengel could do autopsies

• Multiple eponyms: Santavuori, Haltia, Jansky,
• Multiple eponyms: Santavuori, Haltia, Jansky,

Batten, Bielschowsky, Spielmeyer, Sjogren, Kufs
Batten, Bielschowsky, Spielmeyer, Sjogren, Kufs

First clinicopathological correlation by F.E. Batten, 1903 • Defines “familial cerebromacular
First clinicopathological
correlation by F.E. Batten, 1903
• Defines “familial cerebromacular

degeneration”
degeneration”

• Later on in 1914 separates this collection of
• Later on in 1914 separates this collection of

diseases from Tay-Sachs
diseases from Tay-Sachs

Considered “geographically ubiquitous”
Considered “geographically
ubiquitous”

• General frequency 1 per 12,500 births • Enriched gene frequency in Finland where
• General frequency 1 per 12,500 births
• Enriched gene frequency in Finland where

infantile and juvenile forms are more prevalent
infantile and juvenile forms are more
prevalent

• All forms autosomal recessive except for
• All forms autosomal recessive except for

rare instances of autosomal dominant mode of inheritance in some adults
rare instances of autosomal dominant mode
of inheritance in some adults

LINCL is most common (35%) with a mean age-of- onset around 3 yrs. JNCL is slightly less frequent (32%) with a mean age-of-onset of 8 yrs; INCL ranked third (23%) with a mean age-of-onset 11 months; Adult form of the disease was the least common (10%) with a mean age-of-onset 25 yrs.

Pedigree
Pedigree

• S.P.’s mother is Finnish and her father is from Estonia - ? consanguinity, in that Estonia and Finland were once united and root language is the same from these two regions

was determined to be unaffected
